doc.field: The Virginia W. Warthin collection consists of 13 black-and-white images of late 19th century Brooklyn and Manhattan as well as two 1855 school attendance certificates from P.S. 6 awarded to family members of Warthin's.

The Virginia W. Warthin collection consists of 13 black-and-white images of late 19th century Brooklyn and Manhattan as well as two 1855 school attendance certificates from P.S. 6 awarded to family members of Warthin's.

The Virginia W. Warthin collection consists of 13 black-and-white images of late 19th century Brooklyn and Manhattan as well as two 1855 school attendance certificates from P.S. 6 awarded to family members of Warthin's. The collection includes one albumen print showing a street scene of the Blizzard of 1888 as seen from Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn Heights, as well as 12 halftone reproductions of photographs and illustrations of views of the Brooklyn waterfront looking towards the lower Manhattan cityscape; a view of the Louis Bossert and Son Box Factory building in Brooklyn; and views of 19th century skyscrapers and surrounding buildings in lower Manhattan. The two school attendance certificates were awarded to Virginia Eaton, Warthin's grandmother, and Sarah Eaton, Warthin's great aunt.

Virginia W. Warthin (nee Whittier; 1912-1995) was the great granddaughter of James Eaton, a Brooklyn resident who owned land on Schermerhorn Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood. Her grandmother and great aunt were Virginia and Sarah Eaton who grew up in Brooklyn and attended public schools, including P.S. 6. In 1918, the family's land on Schermerhorn Street was taken by eminent domain on which the city built the Children's Court. The family then moved to Sidney Place, also in Brooklyn Heights. Virginia W. Warthin attended Brooklyn Friends School. She later married Thomas A. Warthin, a physician, and they had three sons. After retirement, the Warthins lived in Walpole, MA.
If digital surrogates exist, they should be used in place of the originals whenever possible.
